Name: Lithium hydride
Description: LiH is a chemical compound that reacts explosively with water to give hydrogen gas and LiOH, which is caustic. Consequently, LiH dust can explode in humid air, or even in dry air due to static electricity. With a molecular mass of slightly less than 8, it is the lightest ionic compound.

Name: Hydrogen fluoride
Description: Hydrogen fluoride is a highly dangerous gas, forming corrosive and penetrating hydrofluoric acid upon contact with moisture. t is an important feedstock in the preparation of many important compounds including pharmaceuticals and polymers

Name: Calcium hydride
Description: Calcium hydride has been used for hydrogen production and as drying agent.

Name: Iron dihydride
Description: Even though complexes containing dihydridoiron was known since 1931, the simple compound  is only a much more recent discovery.

Name: hydorgen sulfide
Description: Hydrogen sulfide is commonly found in raw natural gas and biogas. It is a broad-spectrum poison, meaning that it can poison several different systems in the body, although the nervous system is most affected.

Name: Aluminium hydride
Description: Alane is a polymer. Aluminium hydride have been discussed for storing hydrogen in hydrogen-fueled vehicles.

Name: Hydrogen nitride
Description: Ammonia contributes significantly to the nutritional needs of terrestrial organisms by serving as a precursor to food and fertilizers. Ammonia, either directly or indirectly, is also a building block for the synthesis of many pharmaceutical products and is used in many commercial cleaning products

Name: Carbon tetrahydride
Description: Methane is the main constituent of natural gas. The relative abundance of methane on Earth makes it an attractive fuel, though capturing and storing it poses challenges due to its gaseous state under normal conditions. It is found both below ground and under the sea floor.

Name: Hydrogen peroxide
Description: Hydrogen peroxide is unstable and slowly decomposes in the presence of base or a catalyst. It is found in biological systems including the human body.
Appearance: Very light blue color and colorless in solution

Name: Copper peroxide
Description: Copper peroxide readily decomposes at temperatures above 6°C whn wet. It is far more stable when dry.

Name: Hydrogen dioxide
Description: Water is a transparent chemical substance that is the main constituent of Earth's streams, lakes, and oceans, and the fluids of most living organisms. Its molecule contains one oxygen and two hydrogen atoms that are connected by covalent bonds

Name: Lithium oxide
Description: Lithium oxide is used as a flux in ceramic glazes and creates blues with copper and pinks with cobalt.

Name: nitrous oxide
Description: Nitrous oxide has significant medical uses, especially in surgery and dentistry, for its anaesthetic and analgesic effects. Its name "laughing gas" is due to the euphoric effects upon inhaling it.

Name: Carbon monoxide
Description: Carbon monoxide is toxic to hemoglobic animals (both invertebrate and vertebrate, including humans) when encountered in high concentrations , although it is also produced in normal animal metabolism in low quantities, and is thought to have some normal biological functions.

Name: Calcium oxide
Description: The major use of quicklime is in the basic oxygen steelmaking (BOS) process to neutralize acidic oxides in order to produce a basic molten slag.

Name: Iron (II) oxide
Description: Iron(II) oxide makes up approximately 9% of the Earth's mantle. Within the mantle, it may be electrically conductive, which is a possible explanation for perturbations in Earth's rotation not accounted for by accepted models of the mantle's properties.

Name: IIron (II) oxide
Description: Iron(III) oxide was the most common magnetic particle used in all types of magnetic storage and recording media, including magnetic disks (for data storage) and magnetic tape. Also it is used as pigment and to put the final polish on metallic jewelry and lenses, and historically as a cosmetic

Name: Alminium oxide
Description: Being fairly chemically inert and white, aluminium oxide is a favored filler for plastics. Aluminium oxide is a common ingredient in sunscreen and is sometimes present in cosmetics such as blush, lipstick, and nail polish. It is an insulator used as substrate for integrated circuits.

Name: carbon dioxide
Description: It occurs naturally in Earth's atmosphere with natural sources including volcanoes, hot springs and geysers. Because it is soluble in water, it occurs naturally in groundwater, rivers and lakes. It is produced by all aerobic organisms when they metabolize carbohydrates and lipids to produce energy by respiration.

Name: Sulfur dioxide
Description: At standard atmosphere, it is a toxic gas with a pungent, irritating smell. It is released naturally by volcanic activity. It is found on Earth and exists in very small concentrations and in the atmosphere. It is considered that endogenous sulfur dioxide plays a significant physiological role in regulating cardiac and blood vessel function.

Name: Sodium hydroxide
Description: Sodium hydroxide is also known as lye and caustic soda. It is used in many industries in the manufacture of pulp and paper, textiles, drinking water, soaps and detergents and as a drain cleaner.

Name: Potassium hydroxide
Description: Potassium hydroxide is noteworthy as the precursor to most soft and liquid soaps as well as numerous potassium-containing chemicals.

Name: Copper (II) hydroxide
Description: It is  used widely in the aquarium industry for its ability to destroy external parasites in fish, including flukes, marine ich, brook and marine velvet, without killing the fish.

Name: Aluminium hydroxide
Description: Aluminium hydroxide is used as an antacid in humans and animals (mainly cats and dogs). It is also used as a fire retardant filler for polymer applications.

Name: Lithium chloride
Description: Lithium chloride is mainly used for the production of lithium metal by electrolysis. Also, in biochemical applications, it can be used to precipitate RNA from cellular extracts

Name: Sodium chloride
Description: Sodium chloride is the salt most responsible for the salinity of seawater and of the extracellular fluid of many multicellular organisms. In the form of edible or table salt it is commonly used as a condiment and food preservative.

Name: Calcium chloride
Description: Calcium chloride is used to increase the water hardness in swimming pools. This process reduces the erosion of the concrete in the pool. It is injected to treat internal hydrofluoric acid burns.

Name: Aluminium chloride
Description: Aluminium chloride is probably the most commonly used Lewis acid and also one of the most powerful. Hydrated aluminium chloride is a common component in antiperspirants at low concentrations.

Name: Chloric (I) acid
Description: In biology, hypochlorous acid is generated in activated neutrophils for destruction of bacteria

Name: Sulfoxylic acid
Description: It is an unstable oxoacid of sulfur.

Name: Sulfurous acid
Description: Sulfurous acid can be used as reducing agents and as disinfectants. It is also used as mild bleaches. It is used as a food additive.

Name: Sulfuric acid
Description: Sulfuric acid is a highly corrosive strong mineral acid, it can lead to permanent blindness if splashed onto eyes and irreversible damage if swallowed. Principal uses include mineral processing, fertilizer manufacturing, oil refining, wastewater processing, and chemical synthesis.

Name: Glucose
Description: Glucose circulates in the blood of animals as blood sugar. It is made during photosynthesis from water and carbon dioxide, using energy from sunlight. It is the most important source of energy for cellular respiration. Glucose is stored as a polymer, in plants as starch and in animals as glycogen.

Name: Hydrogen and Oxygen
Description: Hydrogen is the lightest element on the periodic table.  Oxygen is the third-most abundant element in the universe, after hydrogen and helium.
